intro: Couratari aulacocarpa, commonly known as the Brazilian nut tree, is a tropical evergreen tree native to the Amazon basin. It belongs to the family Lecythidaceae and is characterized by its large, buttressed roots and smooth, dark-barked trunk. The tree produces a large, woody fruit that contains up to 20 edible seeds, known as Brazil nuts. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and have a velvety texture, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense inflorescences. The plant plays an important ecological role in its habitat, supporting a diverse array of wildlife.
